ceterms:administrationProcess.ceterms:description: This NOCTI assessment  is delivered in an online  format and consists of a written component which is used to measure certain aspects of occupational competence such as factual knowledge and theoretical knowledge. NOCTI assessments must be administered in a proctored environment and can be delivered in one, two, or three sessions.

ceterms:jurisdiction.ceterms:description: This assessment is available throughout North America.

ceterms:administrationProcess.ceterms:processFrequency: Administration frequency is determined by the testing site.
ceterms:administrationProcess.ceterms:processMethodDescription: Administration occurs at an approved NOCTI testing site in a proctored environment.
ceterms:administrationProcess.ceterms:processStandardsDescription: Administration procedures are proprietary and are accessible to testing sites through a password-protected user interface.
ceterms:administrationProcess.ceterms:scoringMethodDescription: Each multiple-choice item is worth one point.  If an individual answers an item correctly, one point is given.  If an individual answers an item incorrectly, no points are given.  All items that are not answered are counted as incorrect.  Scores are calculated by standard area and by total.  Standard scores are determined by dividing the number of questions answered correctly by the number possible within the standard.  Standard scores are considered weighted because each standard does not contain the same number of questions.  Scores are represented by percentages.  A total score is calculated by dividing the total number of questions answered correctly across all standard areas by the total number of points possible across standard areas.
ceterms:administrationProcess.ceterms:scoringMethodExampleDescription: NOCTI's standard score report package includes individual, group, and comparative reports.  Along with total scores, the subscores included in the report assist in easily identifying student and program gains as well as areas for improvement.
ceterms:administrationProcess.ceterms:verificationMethodDescription:
A key strength of all NOCTI assessments concerns content validity. That validity is based upon the fact that each assessment is built upon national/industry standards and reflects the critical core competencies required in the occupation as reflected in associated job-task analyses performed during the development/revision process. Since NOCTI’s assessment development methods rely on subject matter experts to assess the relationship between the assessment content and the defined universe of the job title, NOCTI assessments are a content valid measure of the required skills in a given job title. The Standards for Educational and Psychological Testing (2014) state that content-related evidence demonstrates the degree to which the sample of items, tasks, or questions on a test are representative of some defined universe or domain of content. The methods often rely on expert judgments to assess this relationship. Thus, the content validity of NOCTI Assessments is in accordance with the Standards endorsed by the American Educational Research Association (AERA), the American Psychological Association (APA) and the National Council on Measurement in Education (NCME).

The reliability of an assessment refers to its consistency of measurement (i.e., the absence of measurement errors). NOCTI works to ensure that all of the assessments that we create have a stable and consistent performance of measurement. One approach used to demonstrate that an assessment is providing a reliable measurement of participant skill and/or knowledge is internal consistency. This measure is often used with written (cognitive) assessments and is calculated using a statistical software package such as SPSS or item analysis programs; NOCTI utilizes both types of programs.  The higher the internal consistency the more reliable the assessment.

ceterms:assesses.ceterms:targetNodeName: Apply professional standards when interacting with patients and family
Identify and interpret medical terminology
Maintain appropriate infection control procedures
Apply knowledge of anatomy and physiology
Apply reading skills in a health science career environment
Apply writing skills in a health science career environment
Apply mathematical skills in a health science career environment
Apply science skills in a health science career environment
Describe the relationships, roles, and responsibilities among healthcare professionals
Analyze the impact on healthcare systems based on changes in technology, epidemiology, managed care, etc.
Apply appropriate laws, regulations, and industry standards to healthcare situations
Identify ethical issues and demonstrate ethical behavior in healthcare situations
Communicate with patients using appropriate language and level, including using appropriate techniques for communicating with special needs patients (e.g., hard of hearing)
Apply listening skills and interpret verbal and nonverbal behaviors to enhance communication with coworkers and patients
Interpret and use tables, charts, and figures to support written and oral communication
Use word processing, presentation software, and email applications to prepare communication
Use spreadsheet and database applications to manage and communicate data and information
Use problem solving and critical thinking skills to locate credible sources of information about problems and determine appropriate methods for investigating causes
Use problem solving and critical thinking skills to determine root causes of problems to suggest and evaluate solutions
Apply leadership qualities to improve the quality of work and the work environment
Work effectively in a team environment to improve the quality of work and the work environment
Identify and practice appropriate safety and health procedures for health occupations
Demonstrate appropriate emergency and first aid knowledge and procedures for health occupations
Identify and practice appropriate environmental procedures for health occupations
Demonstrate appropriate workplace behavior related to a health occupations career
Develop career readiness skills to advance in health occupations
Read, interpret, and extract information from medical documents, applying knowledge of medical terminology, billing, and diagnostic codes
Establish and maintain record storage systems within legal guidelines and protocols
Collect and interpret health information data for a variety of purposes (e.g., determining community health information needs)
Identify job opportunities and responsibilities within the health informatics field

ceterms:assessmentExampleDescription:
A patient diagnosed with arthritis may be referred to a
A. gastrologist
B. cardiologist
C. dermatologist
D. rheumatologist
ceterms:deliveryTypeDescription: This assessment is delivered in a web-based delivery system.
ceterms:description: This industry-based credential is included in NOCTI’s Pathway assessment battery. Pathway assessments measure knowledge and skills at a broader level than the Job Ready assessments and focus on the Pathways established as part of the national career cluster model. Pathway assessments are delivered entirely online which allows NOCTI to include engaging interactive items.   This online assessment can be used at the secondary, post-secondary, and adult levels and is tied to the NOCTI Workforce Competency Credential.  Individuals meeting a minimum benchmark also have the opportunity to earn college credit.  More specific information about the standards and competencies measured can be found in the Assessment Blueprint at:  http://nocti.org/blueprint.cfm.

ceterms:developmentProcess.ceterms:description: NOCTI test development/revision committees are convened for each assessment to be developed or revised.  Subject matter experts in the occupational area are recruited.  Subject matter experts must have three years of experience in the occupational area (teaching the occupational area is considered as qualifying experience).  Committees consist of representatives from business/industry and both secondary and post-secondary education.  Geographical representation is also taken into consideration.

ceterms:jurisdiction.ceterms:description: This assessment is available throughout North America.

ceterms:developmentProcess.ceterms:processFrequency: New development occurs on an as needed basis.
ceterms:developmentProcess.ceterms:processMethodDescription:
If a current and complete nationally validated task list is not available for an occupation, a job and task analysis is performed and validated by the committee.  The resulting critical core competencies, tasks and steps are then ranked and quantified to create a blueprint for the assessment being developed.  Once the blueprint is developed, written test questions and performance test jobs are developed or revised to reflect the stated specifications.  Committee members are asked to determine which critical core competencies are best illustrated on the written and performance portions of the test and which can effectively be measured on both components.

NOCTI staff provides each committee member with all appropriate test-related materials.  In addition, all appropriate related supportive curriculum materials as well as item writing guidelines are provided.   Assessments are developed in accordance with the committee’s established blueprint and recommendations.  NOCTI staff provides available relevant test items to the committee members from the NOCTI item bank.

Once the draft test is assembled, a bias review is performed on all items/jobs in the new test and appropriate revisions are made.

Each NOCTI written test is subjected to a readability analysis to ensure the test parallels, but does not exceed, the reading level required in the industry. 

The new assessment is pilot tested on a sample of individuals to ensure times/job criteria on the performance test are appropriate and to determine that items on the written test are functioning properly.  The sample includes representation from various areas of the country.  The results of the pilot tests are compiled and analyzed through an item analysis.  The results of the item analysis indicate item difficulty and discrimination, mean, standard deviation, range of scores, Kuder-Richardson 20 or Cronbach’s Alpha reliability index, and the standard error of measurement.

NOCTI provides clients with a variety of cut score options.  NOCTI provides normative data that may be used as a benchmark as well as criterion-referenced cut scores for each of its job ready assessments.  Clients also have the option of setting their own cut scores on the assessments.
ceterms:developmentProcess.ceterms:processStandardsDescription: The Testing Standards are a product of the American Educational Research Association, the American Psychological Association (APA), and the National Council on Measurement in Education (NCME). Published collaboratively by the three organizations since 1966, it represents the gold standard in guidance on testing in the United States and in many other countries.
ceterms:developmentProcess.ceterms:scoringMethodDescription: Each multiple-choice item is worth one point.  If an individual answers an item correctly, one point is given.  If an individual answers an item incorrectly, no points are given.  All items that are not answered are counted as incorrect.  Scores are calculated by standard area and by total.  Standard scores are determined by dividing the number of questions answered correctly by the number possible within the standard.  Standard scores are considered weighted because each standard does not contain the same number of questions.  Scores are represented by percentages.  A total score is calculated by dividing the total number of questions answered correctly across all standard areas by the total number of points possible across standard areas.
ceterms:developmentProcess.ceterms:scoringMethodExampleDescription: NOCTI's standard score report package includes individual, group, and comparative reports. Along with total scores, the sub-scores included in the report assist in easily identifying student and program gains as well as areas for improvement.

A key strength of all NOCTI assessments concerns content validity. That validity is based upon the fact that each assessment is built upon national/industry standards and reflects the critical core competencies required in the occupation as reflected in associated job-task analyses performed during the development/revision process. Since NOCTI’s assessment development methods rely on subject matter experts to assess the relationship between the assessment content and the defined universe of the job title, NOCTI assessments are a content valid measure of the required skills in a given job title. The Standards for Educational and Psychological Testing (2014) state that content-related evidence demonstrates the degree to which the sample of items, tasks, or questions on a test are representative of some defined universe or domain of content. The methods often rely on expert judgments to assess this relationship. Thus, the content validity of NOCTI Assessments is in accordance with the Standards endorsed by the American Educational Research Association (AERA), the American Psychological Association (APA) and the National Council on Measurement in Education (NCME).

The reliability of an assessment refers to its consistency of measurement (i.e., the absence of measurement errors). NOCTI works to ensure that all of the assessments that we create have a stable and consistent performance of measurement. This measure is often used with written (cognitive) assessments and is calculated using a statistical software package such as SPSS or item analysis programs; NOCTI utilizes both types of programs.  The higher the internal consistency the more reliable the assessment.

ceterms:estimatedCost.ceterms:description: The cost of the assessment per test taker includes access to the assessment and a score report.
ceterms:estimatedCost.ceterms:name: Assessment Cost

ceterms:instructionalProgramType.ceterms:targetNodeDescription: Any instructional program in health and medical administrative services not listed above.
ceterms:instructionalProgramType.ceterms:targetNodeName: Health and Medical Administrative Services, Other

ceterms:jurisdiction.ceterms:description: This credential is available throughout North America.

ceterms:maintenanceProcess.ceterms:description:
Advancements in technology, coupled with changes in occupational practices, result in the need to periodically review and update NOCTI assessments.  Assessments are selected for revision based on a rotation schedule, comments received from users, and on changes in the occupation.  When NOCTI determines that an assessment must be revised, a revision committee is convened with the same representation of content experts as the test development committees.  The revision committee re-evaluates the assessment and changes are made as recommended.  

User comments on assessments are reviewed, sent to subject matter experts if appropriate, and resolved on an ongoing basis.  Minor changes that do not affect the content or scoring rubric of the test are made between revision cycles; major changes are addressed during the revision process which typically occurs every three years.

ceterms:jurisdiction.ceterms:description: This assessment is available throughout North America.

ceterms:maintenanceProcess.ceterms:processFrequency: In general, assessment revision occurs every two to three years.

ceterms:maintenanceProcess.ceterms:processStandardsDescription: The Testing Standards are a product of the American Educational Research Association, the American Psychological Association (APA), and the National Council on Measurement in Education (NCME). Published collaboratively by the three organizations since 1966, it represents the gold standard in guidance on testing in the United States and in many other countries.
ceterms:maintenanceProcess.ceterms:scoringMethodDescription:
Written assessments consist of a multiple-choice format with four options per item and one correct answer.   Some items may contain graphics that must be referred to in order to answer an item.  Others may provide a scenario to assist in selecting the correct answer.  

Each multiple-choice item is worth one point.  If an individual answers an item correctly, one point is given.  If an individual answers an item incorrectly, no points are given.  All items that are not answered are counted as incorrect.  Scores are calculated by standard area and by total.  Standard scores are determined by dividing the number of questions answered correctly by the number possible within the standard.  Standard scores are considered weighted because each standard does not contain the same number of questions.  Scores are represented by percentages.  A total score is calculated by dividing the total number of questions answered correctly across all standard areas by the total number of points possible across standard areas.
ceterms:maintenanceProcess.ceterms:scoringMethodExampleDescription: NOCTI's standard score report package includes individual, group, and comparative reports. Along with total scores, the sub-scores included in the report assist in easily identifying student and program gains as well as areas for improvement.

The higher the internal consistency the more reliable the assessment.

ceterms:recommends.ceterms:description: NOCTI Study Guides provide a study checklist for each standard on the multiple-choice test  and for all jobs included on the performance test.  Teachers and students can work together to building confidence and knowledge as they prepare for NOCTI testing.

ceterms:estimatedCost.ceterms:description: Study guides are available in packages of 10 or sets of 5.  Each package includes a teacher companion guide and individual student study guides.

ceterms:jurisdiction.ceterms:description: This assessment is available throughout North America.
